remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Good morning, thank you for coming in today. I understand you have noticed bright red blood from your ostomy and some mild epigastric tenderness. Can you tell me more about when you first noticed these symptoms and if you have experienced any changes in the amount or frequency of bleeding?

Um, good morning. Well, I first noticed the bright red blood from my ostomy yesterday. It kind of startled me. I’m not sure exactly how much, but it seemed like a fair bit. I’ve also been feeling a little short of breath since then. Should I be worried?

I can completely understand why this has made you feel anxious—it’s always concerning to notice new symptoms like bleeding and shortness of breath. To help guide my assessment, can you tell me if you have experienced any dizziness, fainting, or a rapid heartbeat along with these symptoms?
Well, um… I haven’t fainted, but I have felt a bit light-headed. And, actually, I’ve noticed some chest pressure too. It’s making me pretty anxious.

I can understand why you’re experiencing anxious—experiencing bright red blood from your ostomy along with chest pressure and light-headedness is understandably concerning. To help with my assessment, have you noticed any black or tarry output from your ostomy, or has it all been bright red blood?

remedi_labels.value: black or tarry output from ostomy

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Um, let me think… No, I haven’t seen any black or tarry output from my ostomy. It’s just been bright red blood, really. I keep examinationing to see if it changes, but so far it’s stayed the same. Is that a bad sign?

remedi_labels.value: no black or tarry output from ostomy
Is bright red blood a bad sign?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Thank you for monitoring your symptoms so closely—it’s helpful for your assessment. Since you mentioned mild epigastric tenderness, have you experienced any nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain in addition to the tenderness?

Well, um, I haven’t really had any nausea or vomiting. The tenderness in my upper belly is there, but it’s not exactly painful—just a little uncomfortable. I keep worrying about the bright red blood from my ostomy though. It’s making me pretty anxious, especially with the mild epigastric tenderness.

I can understand why you’d be worried—assessing bright red blood from your ostomy and experiencing short of breath can be very unsettling. To help with my assessment, have you noticed any increase in your shortness of breath with activity, or does it occur even while you are resting?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Um, let me think… I guess the shortness of breath gets a little worse when I’m moving around, like if I get up to go to the bathroom or walk across the room. remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Thank you for sharing these details—it helps guide my assessment. Given your symptoms of bright red blood per ostomy and light-headedness, have you noticed any palpitations or irregular heartbeats since these symptoms began?

I know I have a history of coronary artery disease and, um, I’ve had anginal symptoms before. Could this be anginal symptoms secondary to demand ischemia from the anemia? I’m just worried that the bleeding is making my heart work harder. Should I be really concerned about that?

I’m just really worried about all these symptoms happening together—the bleeding, the light-headedness, the chest pressure, and now the fatigue. Is this something that can be managed, or should I be preparing for something more serious?
